learning_outcomes: Recognize and reproduce basic sounds of the Breton alphabet.
Understand and use familiar everyday expressions and very basic phrases (e.g., greetings, introductions).
Introduce him/herself and others simply (e.g., Me eo... - I am...).
Ask and answer simple questions about personal details (name, origin).
Interact in a very simple way if the other person speaks slowly, clearly, and is prepared to help.
Recognize familiar names, words, and very simple sentences in Breton.
language_focus_topics: The Breton Alphabet (Lizherenneg) and pronunciation of letters (including ch, c'h, gn,ilh).
Basic pronunciation rules: Vowel sounds (including nasal vowels likeañ, eñ, iñ, oñ, uñ). Consonant sounds.
Introduction to Consonant Mutations: Basic concept of soft mutation (kemmadurioù meddal) with very common words (e.g., after 'da' - your).
Nouns: Introduction to grammatical gender (masculine/feminine). Singular nouns.
Articles: Definite articles (an, al, ar). Indefinite articles (un, ul, ur).
Pronouns: Personal pronouns (me, te, eñ, hi, ni, c'hwi, int/i).
Verbs: Present tense of 'bezañ' (to be) - basic forms (on, out, eo/zo, omp, oc'h, int).
Verbs: Present tense of 'endevout/kaout' (to have) - basic forms (am eus, az peus, en deus/he deus).
Basic Sentence Structure: Verb-Subject-Object (VSO) tendency for simple sentences. Simple affirmative and negative statements.
Negation: 'ne ... ket' structure around the verb (e.g., Ne glevan ket - I don't hear).
Simple Questions: Intonation. Basic question words (Piv? Petra? Pelec'h? Pegoulz?).
vocabulary_topics: Greetings: Demat, Kenavo, Salud, Mont a ra? Mat an traoù?, Trist eo an amzer.
Introductions & Personal Information: Pe anv out? ... eo ma anv. Plijet bras. Eus pelec'h out? Eus ... on.
Courtesy: Trugarez, Mar plij, Digarezit.
Basic responses: Ya, Nann / N'eo ket.
Numbers: 0-10 (zero-dek).
Colors: ruz, glas, gwer, melen, du, gwenn (basic).
Family: mamm, tad, breur, c'hoar (basic).
Common Objects: levr, taol, kador, ti, karr, pellgomz.
Basic Food & Drink: bara, dour, laezh, kafe, te, kig, pesked.
Classroom language: Adlavarit, mar plij. Ne gomprenan ket.

Nasal vowels (an, añ, ein, eñ, eun, euñ, in, iñ, on, oñ, oun, uñ).
Distinction between 'c'h' /χ/ and 'h' /h/ or /Ø/.
The 'zh' sound (often /z/, but /h/ in some dialects).
Word stress (generally penultimate, but can vary, especially with suffixes or in Vannetais dialect).
Basic intonation for statements and simple questions.

learning_outcomes: Understand and use familiar everyday expressions and frequently used phrases related to areas of most immediate relevance (e.g., basic personal and family information, shopping, local geography, telling time).
Communicate in simple and routine tasks requiring a simple and direct exchange of information on familiar matters.

language_focus_topics: Review A0: Alphabet, basic pronunciation, bezañ/endevout (present), articles, basic mutations.
Nouns: Plural formation (common suffixes: -où, -ed, -ien; internal vowel changes - basic). Gender agreement with articles.
Adjectives: Basic agreement (often invariable or simple feminine forms). Position (usually after the noun).
Verbs: Present tense of common regular verbs (e.g., kanañ - to sing, lenn - to read, skrivañ - to write). Verbal noun as infinitive.
Verbs: Past tense (Amzer dremenet strizh - e.g., -as, -is endings or with 'ober' + verbal noun). Future tense (Amzer da zont - e.g., -o, -i endings or with 'mont da' + verbal noun).
Consonant Mutations: More practice with soft mutation (after 'da', 'e', common prepositions). Introduction to spirant mutation (kemmadur c'hwezh) after 'va', 'he', 'o'.
Pronouns: Possessive determiners (ma, da, e, he, hon, ho, o + mutations).

Prepositions: Common simple prepositions (e.g., e, e-barzh - in; war - on; da - to; gant - with; eus - from; dre - through). Inflected prepositions (1st/2nd person singular of common ones like 'din' - to me, 'ganin' - with me).
Numbers: 0-20. Basic ordinal numbers (kentañ, eil...).
Sentence Structure: Simple VSO and SVO patterns. Using particles like 'a', 'e', 'o' with verbs.
vocabulary_topics: Review A0 vocabulary.
Personal information: Family members (extended), age, professions.
Daily routine: Describing typical daily activities with times.
Food & Drink: Common food items, drinks, meals (merenn, koan), ordering in a restaurant.
Shopping: Types of shops (stal), common items, prices, quantities.
Places in town: straed, plasenn, liorzh, sinema, mirdi, iliz, ti-kêr, post, bank.
Transport: karr-boutin/bus, tren, metro, taxi, karr-nij, marc'h-houarn. Buying tickets.
Time: Telling the time, days of the week, months, seasons, dates.
Weather: Describing weather conditions (tomm eo, yen eo, glav a ra, erc'h a ra).
Hobbies & interests (lenn, sellet ouzh ar skinwel, selaou sonerezh).
Clothing: Common items.

Vowel length (short vs. long vowels - basic awareness).

learning_outcomes: Understand sentences and frequently used expressions related to areas of immediate personal relevance in Breton.
Communicate in simple and routine tasks in Breton requiring a simple and direct exchange of information on familiar matters.

language_focus_topics: Review A1: Plurals, basic tenses (present, past, future), common mutations (soft, spirant), possessives, simple prepositions.
Verbs: Imperfect tense (Amzer dremenet amstrizh - e.g., -e,-es,-e,-emp,-ec'h,-ent). Conditional mood (Amzer divizout - e.g., -fe,-fes,-fe,-femp,-fec'h,-fent).
Verbs: Common irregular verbs (mont - to go, dont - to come, ober - to do, gallout - can, gouzout - know) in present, past, future, conditional.
Consonant Mutations: Hard mutation (kemmadur kalet) after 'ho', 'az'. Mixed mutation (kemmadur mesket). Reinforce all four mutations in context.
Pronouns: Inflected prepositions (full paradigm for common ones like 'gant', 'da', 'evit'). Object pronouns (direct/indirect - often expressed with inflected prepositions or word order).
Adjectives: Comparative (-oc'h) and superlative (-añ) forms. Agreement and position.
Adverbs: Formation from adjectives (e.g., with 'mod' or 'doare'). Adverbs of time, place, manner, frequency.
Numbers: Up to 1000. Using numbers with nouns (mutations may apply).
Relative clauses (simple, with 'a', 'hag a').

Daily life and routines: More complex sequences, discussing habits.

Verbs: Subjunctive mood (Doare-sujañt) - present and imperfect forms and uses (e.g., after 'evit ma', 'a-raok ma').
Verbal Noun: Expanded uses (e.g., as subject/object, after prepositions).
Passive voice constructions.
